Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale Models of Bacterial Chemotaxis and Phase Segregation in Axons
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates fundamental questions of a multiscale nature in two biological systems. The first topic concerns chemotaxis of cell populations, which is the directed movement of cells in response to external chemical signals. Current continuum models for chemotaxis of cell populations using partial differential equations are phenomenological and do not match recent experimental data. This research investigates this issue in the context of bacterial chemotaxis, and derive continuum models from cell-based models based on the detailed biochemistry of cell signaling. This task involves development of new multiscale methods that deal with nonlinearities of single-cell dynamics and overlapping time scales. The second topic concerns the dynamics and organization of the axonal cytoskeleton. A fundamental question in axonal physiology is to understand how the structure of the axonal cytoskeleton is developed and maintained in health and how it gets perturbed in diseases. This research investigates the mechanisms that lead to the segregation of axonal cytoskeletal molecules observed in diseases using multiscale models, and will be conducted in close collaboration with experimentalists.

Complex biological systems involve multiple space and time scales. To completely understand these systems, multiscale models and methods are essential tools. This research addresses questions of a multiscale nature in two biological systems by developing new multiscale models and methods. The first concerns the directed cell movement in response to chemical signals, which is crucial in bacteria-induced infections, bioremediation, wound healing, cancer metastasis, and embryonic development. This research will lead to quantitative, mechanistic models for directed movement of bacterial populations. These models will enhance our ability to predict and control health problems such as bacteria-associated infections and environmental problems such as bioremediation. The resulting multiscale analysis framework is broadly applicable to study collective movement of other types of cells, ants, birds and animals, and thus this research has far-reaching impacts in medicine and ecology. The second topic concerns the physiology of axons, which are long thin projections of nerve cells. Maintaining the regular shape and organization of the axonal cytoskeleton is critical for the normal functioning of neurons. How is the normal organization of the axonal cytoskeleton maintained and established in health? How is it perturbed in neurodegenerative diseases? This research investigates these questions using multiscale models that integrate the detailed biology of the axonal cytoskeletal molecules. This research will shed light on the underlying mechanisms of many neurodegenerative diseases such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. This project will also involve cross-disciplinary training of undergraduate and graduate students with diverse backgrounds at the interface between multiscale modeling and wet-lab experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded two research projects of PI Xue. The proposed research goals have been fully achieved during the funding period.

The first project is about multiscale analysis of bacterial chemotaxis. Chemotaxis is the directed cell movement in response to external chemical signals, which is crucial in many multicellular processes such as bacterial infections, bioremediation and wound healing. At the population level, it has been widely modeled by PDEs such as the PKS chemotaxis equation. However, there are two concerns in using these PDE models. First, they often assume phenomenological forms of cell fluxes, and their relation to mechanistic cellular processes are poorly understood. Second, solutions of these equations do not match recent experimental data on bacterial chemotaxis.

The PI addressed these concerns in the context of bacterial chemotaxis. Starting from a general individual-based model that integrates the detailed, highly nonlinear biochemistry of intracellular signaling, the PI derived the PKS equation under the condition that the external signal gradient is small. The derived equation yielded a general formula that relates the chemotactic sensitivity with the structure and kinetics of the intracellular signaling pathway. The PI used the formula to explain the molecular origin of the logarithmic sensitivity of bacterial chemotaxis. The PI then numerically illustrated that the derived PKS equation provides good approximations to the cell population dynamics when the external signal gradient is static and small, but break down when the external signal gradient becomes large. These comparisons highlight the need to derive new macroscopic, quantitative models for chemotaxis in large signal gradients. To address this need, the PI derived new moment-flux models that are suitable for bacterial chemotaxis in a much larger range of signal gradients. Previous derivations of continuum models rely on quasi-steady state approximations of the internal ODE system, which is only justifiable if cell movement is subject to small external signal gradients along their trajectories. The new moment-flux models corrected this by tracking the deviation of cell’s internal state from its steady state using a few moment variables and justified using numerical simulations.

This research has made a significant step in transforming PDE theories of bacterial chemotaxis from phenomenological to mechanistic, and from qualitative to quantitative. The multiscale analysis framework can be applied to study bacterial movement towards other signals, such as oxygen and light.

The second project is about phase segregation in the axonal cytoskeleton. The axonal cytoskeleton is a dynamic polymer system inside an axon, which is a long, thin projection of a neuron. Under normal conditions two types of cytoskeletal polymers, microtubules (MTs) and neurofilaments (NFs), form a mixture in axons. However, in many neurotoxic and neurodegenerative disorders they separate apart from each other, with microtubules and membranous organelles clustered centrally and neurofilaments displaced to the periphery. This striking segregation precedes abnormal and excessive neurofilament accumulation in these diseases, which in turn leads to focal axonal swellings. These phenomena have been observed for over 40 years now, but a mechanistic explanation of them was lacking.

To address this question, the PI developed a stochastic multiscale model in 2D for the cross-sectional organization of microtubules and neurofilaments. The model describes microtubules, neurofilaments and organelles as interacting particles in a 2D cross-section, and incorporates the stochastic interactions of these particles through molecular motors. Simulations of the model demonstrate that organelles can pull nearby microtubules together, and in the absence of neurofilament transport, this mechanism gradually segregates microtubules from neurofilaments on a time scale of hours, similar to that observed in toxic neuropathies. This suggests that the microtubule-neurofilament segregation is simply a consequence of the selective impairment of neurofilament transport. The model generated the experimentally testable prediction that the rate and extent of segregation will be dependent on the sizes of the moving organelles as well as the density of their traffic. These predictions are being tested in leading experimentalist Anthony Brown's lab. 

This research has advanced our knowledge on two important questions in neuron physiology: how is the normal structure of the axonal cytoskeleton developed and maintained in health, and how does it get perturbed in diseases? The results can lead to significant insights into motor neuron diseases such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. The developed computational tools will be useful in guiding new experiments on the structure and function of the axonal cytoskeleton.

Through these project, the PI trained 7 graduate and 2 undergraduate students on multiscale modeling in biology. The PI also passed her enthusiasm in mathematical biology to young minds through summer camps for gifted high school students and middle school girls, in which she served as faculty advisor and project leader.
